Award.AwardTitle: Impact of Atmospheric Trace Elements on the "Third Pole" Glaciers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of this project is to identify the sources, fluxes, and spatial/temporal distribution of atmospheric trace elements affecting the glaciers of the Himalayan and the Tibetan Plateau (the so-called "Third Pole") from the pre-industrial era (~1500 AD) to present time. An existing set of unique ice cores retrieved from Guliya (Western Tibetan plateau), Naimona'nyi and Dasuopu (Central Himalaya), Puruogangri and Dunde (Central and Northern Tibetean plateau, respectively) will be analyzed for a suite of trace elements, including Ag, Al, As, Bi, Cd, Co, Cr, Cu, Fe, Hg, In, Mn, Mo, Ni, Pb, Rb, Se, Sb, Sn, Sr, Ti, Tl, U, V, and Zn, using inductively-coupled plasma sector field mass spectrometry. These data will allow quantification of trace element fluxes and discrimination, with an unprecedented spatial and temporal resolution, of their natural background (e.g. crustal and volcanic constituents) components from the anthropogenic components (e.g. fossil fuel combustion and non-ferrous metal production).

The assessment of atmospheric trace elements deposition is of great interest to modelers attempting to trace their sources, transport, and fluxes. The spatial and temporal characterization of atmospheric pollution at high elevations in the Third Pole region is needed because recent studies suggest that atmospheric "brown clouds" deposition to the Himalayan glaciers may affect their energy balance, resulting in an acceleration of ablation. Knowledge of the initial quality of the meltwater, resulting from the ongoing shrinking of the glaciers in the Himalaya, is also important for planning the availability of water resources for millions of people who live downstream from these glaciers. Ultimately all these studies serve as a source of fundamental information for policy makers trying to mitigate the impact of trace metals in the environment. This project will be developed in the framework of the Third Pole Environment (TPE) initiative and will reinforce the collaboration between the Byrd Polar Research Center at The Ohio State University and the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research in Beijing (China). The project will support the full involvement of a post-doctoral scholar and a master's degree student in the analysis and study of the ice cores. In addition, a specific outreach program will be developed at the Byrd Polar Research Center: three selected high school teachers and their classes will become familiar with the research activities. They will have an opportunity to participate through videoconferencing which will be recorded and posted online for others to view. Teachers and students everywhere will benefit from this outreach program by having access to educational materials developed in this framework, which will be submitted to the National Science Digital Library and the Ohio Resource Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
South East Asia is one of the fastest developing regions on Earth and has experienced a recent large increase in atmospheric pollution. Glaciers of the nearby Himalayan and Tibetan Plateau mountains (the so-called "Third Pole") are a unique archive that can be used to assess the strength and timing of the onset of atmospheric pollution in a region that is influenced by the monsoon regime, alternating wet and dry seasons.  We have studied atmospheric pollution from trace elements deposited to these glaciers during the last 500 years. A set of ice cores extracted from Guliya (Western Tibetan plateau), Naimona'nyi and Dasuopu (Central Himalaya), Puruogangri and Dunde (Central and Northern Tibetan plateau, respectively) was analyzed. These allowed us to distinguish the natural atmospheric components (e.g. crustal and volcanic constituents) from human contributions (e.g. fossil fuel combustion and non-ferrous metal production) for aerosols deposited from the atmosphere onto the glacier surfaces.

            The Naimona’nyi and Dunde cores illustrate that intense aeolian dust transport can dominate atmospheric pollution deposition to remote areas of the Tibetan Plateau and the Himalayas. In these two locations no obvious contamination was found suggesting that in some remote areas of this mountain region the natural deposition of local dust masks the other chemical species that are transported from distant sources.

            On the Puruogangri ice cap, in a remote area of Central Tibet, we have identified the components of salts, probably transported from the lakes dispersed on the Tibetan Plateau. Salt levels have decreased since the beginning of the 20th century, in association with lower intensity of the westerly winds. At least two volcanic ash depositions have impacted this area over the past 500 years, originating from the Billy Mitchell (1580, Papua New Guinea) and the Parker Peak (1641, Philippines) eruptions. An atmospheric pollution signal started to emerge in this record beginning in the early 1900s, and more substantially after 1935. The metallurgy emission products from the former Soviet Union and especially from central Asia (e.g., Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan) enhanced the atmospheric contamination reaching the Puruogangri ice cap between 1935 and 1980. The impact of this industrial pollution cumulated with hemispheric coal and gasoline combustion. Chinese steel production, accompanying the Great Leap Forward (1958-1961) and the Chinese Cultural Revolution (1966-1976), is less important but may be a source of lead pollution affecting the ice cap between 1958 and 1976. Between 1980 and 1992, pollution originating from developing countries of South (i.e., India) and East (i.e., China) Asia, and transported by the summer monsoons, influenced the Central Tibetan Plateau.

            The Guliya ice cap, on the northwestern margin of the Tibetan Plateau, is much less exposed to the influence of the monsoons. Northern hemisphere coal combustion is an early source of human pollution during the 1850-1950 period, when it increased in Western countries after the Industrial Revolution and decreased in Europe after the 1950s when oil consumption increased. The shift in Europe from coal to oil use was observed in Guliya after ~1950 while the observed post-1980 contamination from phosphate fertilizers, mining/smelting and leaded gasoline combustion originated from Central Asia and western China.

            Finally, at 7200 m altitude in the Himalaya, the Dasuopu ice core provides the highest elevation ice core record ever obtained, offering the best potential to archive also long distant pollution from the western countries. In general we find here the lowest levels of contaminants that are still very variable throughout the year. Remarkably, these low depositions are comparable to those recorded at some polar sites, however, the Dasuopu record shows an increase in aeolian dust deposition during the second half of the 20th century. We use the Dasuopu Glacier ice core also to quantify black carbon deposited onto this glacier over the past 200 years. Black carbon is a contaminant that is a product of incomplete biofuel, hydrocarbon, and biomass combustion, and affects climate by absorbing solar energy in the atmosphere and decreases the light reflected by the snow covered surfaces. Our record indicates that black carbon particle dimensions and depositions to the highest elevations of the Himalaya have increased with time towards the present due to diesel fuel burning.

            This study serves as a source of information for policy makers to diminish the impact of trace metals and black carbon in the environment. This project was developed in the framework of the Third Pole Environment initiative and reinforced the collaboration between the Byrd Polar and Climate Research Center at The Ohio State University and the Institute of Tibetan Plateau Research in Beijing (China). The project supported three female post-doctoral scholars in the analysis and study of the ice cores. An outreach program was developed where internships of two high school students were conducted in our laboratories. A video is now also available at https://vimeo.com/153707736 to present the project to the large public.
